title: Unemployable, angry and the winner of the Bulgari Art Award
text:
Reserved and thoughtful, Qureshi sits in her light-flooded studio behind the ramshackle house she shares with her husband and two sons on Melbourne’s bushy north-eastern outskirts. There’s a conspicuous lack of paint spatters, but Qureshi has been working in the newly built studio for only a month. On her painting desk are hundreds of fine brushes and a tiffin carrier full of the seashells she uses as watercolour palettes.

When she chose to major in traditional miniature Mughal painting, her art school professor in Lahore told her it was career suicide, but Qureshi doesn’t seem the type to be swayed by popular opinion or to take the easy path; the very reason she trained in miniature painting was the painstaking precision required to master it.

On the edge of darkness II (2016), acrylic, gouache, gold leaf and ink on illustration board. Nusra Latif Qureshi

Using both her traditional training and a contemporary visual language, she mixes motifs from the past – a textile pattern or historical photograph perhaps – with ideas from the present. According to AGNSW’s head curator of Australian art, Wayne Tunnicliffe, it’s that combination that sets her work apart.

“She quotes from quite traditional imagery but recontextualises it,” he says. “It’s that sense of history which gives her work a real richness … She looks at culture and thinks about how it’s still shaped by the past.”

I’m honing my anger … trying to make it into a sharp point. — Nusra Latif Qureshi

One of the works acquired by the gallery, Descriptions from the past II – a miniature self-portrait painted in traditional Mughal style – recalls the cultural dislocation Qureshi felt in 2001. In it, the female figure is placed between two golden orbs, symbolising her two worlds. It’s rare to find women represented in historical Mughal paintings, but Qureshi’s figures are almost always female. “It’s to assert my dissent,” she says. If men are in her works, they are “tokens of this or that – usually a negative presence”.

Descriptions from the past II (2001), gouache and gold leaf on wash. Nusra Latif Qureshi

Forever and ever I, another of the gallery’s acquisitions, is about “being absolutely tired of being used as a woman”. The work features a female outline and five female arms wrapped in threads emerging out of a vibrant red orb. “This whole series is about this person wanting her own space,” she says, “wanting to be acknowledged just as herself, not [for] baking a cake or raising a child who can speak three languages.”

The recurring feminist theme is no accident. “I’m honing my anger … trying to make it into a sharp point,” she says. The catalysts for her rage are “too numerous to mention – from big historical injustices to ‘why do I have to pick up the kids today?’”

Advertisement

For Qureshi, the fourth of six children, the defining moment of her childhood came when she was five, when her father, a government engineer, died of a heart attack. Her grief-stricken mother, a teacher, had to work harder and never talked about the family’s loss. Left to deal with it alone, Qureshi sought solace in art. “It can give you relief,” she says. “You can find a language that expresses that trauma without spelling everything out.”

Qureshi in her Melbourne studio. Eamon Gallagher

She doesn’t remember her father, but the pain lingers – and seems to surface in her art. “A lot of my work is about things not being there any more,” she says. “Emotional deprivation, emotional poverty.”

If that makes the viewer uncomfortable, then her job is done; Qureshi aims to create intense works that make the viewer question themselves and the world. “But I’m sensible not to make it ugly,” she says. Using brilliant colours and appealing aesthetics, she draws the viewer in by stealth before packing an emotional punch.

“It has to give you an experience of beauty, of pleasant pain, of something you can think about months later,” she says. “Beauty is an interesting trapping device.”

Also destined for AGNSW: Distant plains of gold (2019) and Knotting the waves (2019). Nusra Latif Qureshi

The gallery and the jeweller

The Bulgari Art Award was established in 2012 in partnership with the Art Gallery of NSW to support mid-career Australian contemporary artists. Previous winners are Michael Zavros (2012); Jon Cattapan (2013); Daniel Boyd (2014); Ildiko Kovacs (2015); Jude Rae (2016); and Tomislav Nikolic (2017).

“It is a very natural collaboration as historically Bulgari’s support for the arts and contemporary design has been an integral part of the brand’s DNA,” says Australia managing director Brad Harvey.

“We are thrilled with this year’s choice. Adding Nusra Latif Qureshi’s work to the amazing alumni of celebrated Bulgari Art Award winners shows the diversity, depth and extraordinary creativity of contemporary art in Australia.”
description: For Nusra Latif Qureshi, painting is an outlet for her rage over all manner of injustices.
